questions.question: Question 1: What is the normal urine output in adults?
questions.explanation:
The average normal urine output is approximately 1500 mL/day. A minimum urine output of 400 
mL/day is essential to excrete the end products of protein metabolism. Fluid loss occurs mainly by four routes: • Lungs: Approximately 400 mL of water is lost in expired air every 24 hours. • Skin: In a temperate climate the loss is between 600 and 1000 mL/day. • Urine: The normal urine output is approximately 1500 mL/day. • Faeces: About 60 and 150 mL of water are lost daily in patients with normal bowel function.

questions.question: Question 2: Which parameter is the best guide to monitor the adequacy of fluid resuscitation in a patient?
questions.explanation:
12 
Sold by @itachibot Urine output is the best measure of organ perfusion and the best monitor for adequacy of fluid 
resuscitation. Adequate end-organ perfusion is best indicated by urine output of >0.5 to 1 mL/kg/h. However, 
it does not give a minute-to-minute value. The level of consciousness is an important marker for cerebral perfusion. The only clinical indicators of perfusion of the gastrointestinal tract and muscular beds are 
measures of lactic acidosis (lactate and base deficit) and mixed venous oxygen saturation. Other options: Option A: Central venous pressure (CVP) is the mean pressure in the superior vena cava, used for 
estimation of preload and right atrial pressure. Normal CVP ranges from 2 to 7 mm Hg (3 to 9 cm 
H2O). A sick or injured patient with a CVP <3 mm Hg is presumed to be volume depleted and 
may be given fluids with relative safety. However, CVP is unreliable in assessing volume status or 
left ventricular function with respect to resusitation. Options C and D: Blood pressure and oxygen saturation do not reflect body fluid levels.

questions.question:
Question 3: A surgery resident during the rounds advised the intern to monitor the burns patient for 
adequate fluid resuscitation and also instructed him to give a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight 
if the patient showed signs of hypoperfusion. All of the following are indications to give bolus 
fluid, except:
questions.explanation:
A low hematocrit does not indicate a need for fluid resuscitation. Instead, a high hematocrit is an indicator of hypoperfusion. Urine output is the best measure to monitor for the adequacy of fluid resuscitation. Urine output 
should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour. If the urine output is below this, the 
infusion rate should be increased by 50%. If the urine output is inadequate and the patient is 
showing signs of hypoperfusion, then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given. Signs of hypoperfusion include: • Restlessness with tachycardia, • Cool peripheries • High hematocrit

questions.question: Question 4: What is the source of endogenous fluids in the body?
questions.explanation:
The source of endogenous fluids for the body is due to oxidation of solid foodstuff. Fluid is derived from both exogenous and endogenous fluids. • Exogenous fluids- Water from beverages, water from food, etc • Endogenous fluids- Water released during oxidation of solid foodstuff Eg: Glucose + O2  CO2 + H2O + ATP The amount of endogenous fluids formed is normally less than 500 ml in 24 hours. However, 
during starvation, this amount is supplemented by water released from the breakdown of body 13 
Sold by @itachibot tissues.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with a stab wound to the abdomen underwent an emergency laparotomy. After the 
damaged intestine was resected, less than 100 cm of jejunum remained and a jejunostomy 
was made. Which of the following is not true?

options.a: The patient is a net secretor
options.b: Water intake should be less than a litre a day
options.c: Ensure adequate resuscitation with hypotonic fluids

questions.explanation:
Net secretors are patients that have less than 100 cm of residual jejunum and a jejunostomy. 
They should not be given hypotonic fluids. The total amount of hypotonic fluids (water) is restricted to less than a liter a day. They are 
encouraged to take glucose and saline replacement solutions. Solutions that have a sodium 
concentration of at least 90 mmol/L (e.g.WHO cholera solution) are given. Antisecretory drugs 
which include H2-receptor antagonists, proton pump inhibitors, and the somatostatin analog 
octreotide, are also used. The patients with short bowel syndrome who have had a jejunostomy and more than 200 cm of 
small bowel resected, are divided into two groups: • Net absorbers- These patients have more than 100 cm of residual jejunum. They absorb more 
water and sodium from the diet that passes through the stoma. These patients can be managed 
without supplementary parenteral fluids. • Net secretors- These patients have less than 100 cm of residual jejunum. As they lose water and 
sodium from their stoma, these patients require supplements.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient with Crohn's disease has multiple skip lesions in the intestine. Surgical resection of 
damaged areas is being planned. Removal of which part will cause steatorrhoea?
questions.explanation:
Ileal resection may lead to steatorrhoea. The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of the 
ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis. Depletion of the 
bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption that presents with steatorrhea. The efficiency of water absorption in the jejunum is 44% and in the is ileum 70%. Resection of 
ileum causes reduced conservation of fluid. Loss of bile salts into the colon affects colonic mucosa, 
causing a reduction in salt and water absorption, which increases stool losses. Small bowel motility is three times slower in the ileum than in the jejunum. In addition, the 
ileocaecal valve may slow the transit. Resection of the ileum results in a significant enhancement 
of gastric motility and acceleration of intestinal transit. 14 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 66-year-old diabetic patient with a frail built comes to the OPD. His wife is concerned about 
his recent weight loss and lack of appetite. Which parameters will you consider while 
assessing his malnutrition using MUST?
questions.explanation:
Age is not a criterion used in MUST. Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) is a five-step screening tool to identify 
malnourished adults or adults at risk of malnutrition.

questions.question:
Question 8: 6 
Sold by @itachibot What is the best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of a Ryle's tube?
questions.explanation:
The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube (RT) is sitting 
with neck flexion. The described position helps in directing the RT towards the esophagus and 
also prevents it from coiling in the oropharynx or entering the trachea. RT, also known as nasogastric (NG) tube, measures 120-125 cm. It has 4 markings at 40cm 
(cardia), 50cm (body), 60cm (pylorus), and 70 cm (duodenum) to indicate the approximate 
position after the placement. Indications for NG tube: • Feeding in patients with dysphagia, decreased appetite, or those who are nil per os (NPO) for 
medical or surgical reasons. • Aspiration of gastric fluid • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus. • ™ollinger-Ellison syndrome • Bowel irrigation The absolute contraindications for an NG tube are severe midface trauma, recent nasal surgery, 
and basilar skull fractures 15 
Sold by @itachibot Steps for the correct insertion of RT in an adult: • Examination of the patient’s nostril for any anatomical abnormalities and then instillation with 
10 ml of 1% lignocaine • NEX method is used to measure the length of the RT: Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of 
the nose. Extend the tube to the earlobe, and then to the xiphisternum. • The patient is asked to sit upright with partial neck flexion. The tip of the Ryle’s tube is 
lubricated and passed along the floor of the nasal passage until a resistance is felt(corresponds to 
nasopharynx) • The patient is subsequently asked to swallow water to guide the tube through the esophagus into 
the stomach until the marked length (based on the NEX method). • NG tube is finally taped to secure it in place. Confirmation of the correct position is done by: • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air • X-ray chest to locate the lead markers • Aspiration of contents and subsequently confirming gastric origin (pH <6 indicates gastric 
placement)

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient in your ward is to be started on enteral nutrition. All of the following can be used as 
means of delivery, except:
questions.explanation:
A peripherally inserted central venous catheter (PICC) line is used for providing parenteral 
nutrition. The term enteral feeding means the delivery of nutrients into the gastrointestinal tract. This can 
be achieved with oral supplements (sip feeding) or with a variety of tube-feeding techniques such 
as nasogastric tubes (Ryle’s), fine-bore feeding tubes, surgical or percutaneous endoscopic 
gastrostomy (PEG). 16 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A young female patient with dysphagia is started on enteral nutrition. Which of the following 
complications is least likely to occur in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The complication least likely to occur in a patient with enteral feeding is hypoglycemia. Metabolic complications related to decreased or increased feeding are commonly seen in total 
parenteral nutrition. Complications of enteral nutrition 1. Tube-related (most common): • Malposition • Displacement • Blockage • Breakage/leakage • Local complications (e.g. erosion of skin/mucosa) 2. Gastrointestinal: • Diarrhoea • Bloating, nausea, vomiting • Abdominal cramps • Aspiration • Constipation 3. Metabolic/biochemical: • Electrolyte disorders • Vitamin, mineral, trace element deficiencies • Drug interactions 4. Infective: • Exogenous (handling contamination) • Endogenous (patient)

questions.question: Question 11: Which dietary component is lacking in patients started on TPN?
questions.explanation:
Fibers are not included in total parenteral nutrition. Total enteral or parenteral nutrition necessitates the provision of the macronutrients, 
carbohydrates, fat and protein, together with vitamins, trace elements, electrolytes, and water. 17 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: 7 
Sold by @itachibot A peripherally inserted central catheter line(PICC) was placed in a patient to provide 
parenteral nutrition. Following the insertion, a chest X-ray was taken, which appeared as 
shown in the image below. Which of the following is the ideal position of the tip of this 
catheter?
questions.explanation:
The ideal position of the tip of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line, is superior vena 
cava. Peripherally inserted central catheters are commonly used for providing parenteral nutrition 
therapy. They are inserted through veins in the upper arm, and guided into the central venous 
system, such that the tip of the catheter enters the superior vena cava. A chest X-ray is taken to 
confirm the position of the tip. PICC lines have the advantage of minimizing inconvenience to the patients and clinicians. 
However, if the patient develops thrombophlebitis, the PICC line may be destroyed. The image below shows (A) a typical PICC line (B) an illustration showing insertion of PICC line 
(C) a patient with PICC line inserted through the upper arm. The image below shows the chest X-ray confirming the position of the tip of the PICC line 
(arrows), in the superior vena cava. 18 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: You are asked to place a central line for providing parenteral nutrition to a critically ill 
patient. Which vein is the most suitable?
questions.explanation:
The subclavian vein is considered the most suitable vein for parenteral nutrition, as the catheter 
lies flat on the chest wall, which optimizes nursing care. Moreover, the rate of infection with 
subclavian venous access is lowest when compared to jugular access and femoral access. Disadvantages of subclavian vein central venous access: • Subclavian vein stenosis • Pneumothorax

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient has been on total parenteral nutrition via a central venous catheter for 5 weeks. All 
of the following should be done, except: 8 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Monitor for any signs of sudden glucose intolerance
options.b: Electrolytes must be checked every 2-3 days
options.c: LFT, BUN must be done once weekly
options.d: Change central venous catheter tube every two weeks

questions.explanation:
A central venous catheter is changed only if the infection is suspected or the catheter is blocked. It 
need not be changed every 2 weeks. Total parenteral nutrition (TPN), also referred to as central parenteral nutrition, requires access to 
a large-diameter vein to deliver the entire nutritional requirements of the individual. The dextrose content of the solution given is high (15% to 25%). All macronutrients and 
micronutrients are deliverable by this route. To monitor or prevent complications, the following steps may be taken: • Infections • Use subclavian vein preferably • Monitor development of glucose intolerance as it is the earliest sign of systemic sepsis • Metabolic complications 19 
Sold by @itachibot • BUN and LFTs weekly • Serum electrolytes every 2-3 days • Intestinal atrophy • Provide at least some nutrients enterally if feasible

questions.question: Question 15: A patient on total parenteral nutrition may develop a deficiency of
questions.explanation:
A patient on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) may develop a deficiency of zinc, among others. The commencement of TPN may precipitate or accentuate underlying nutrient deficiency by 
encouraging anabolism. Complications of TPN: • Infections • Highest risk - femoral vein • Lowest risk - subclavian vein • Metabolic complications • CO2 retention and respiratory insufficiency due to excess calorie infusion • Hepatic steatosis and marked glycogen deposition • Cholestasis and gallstones • Intestinal atrophy • Mucosal atrophy • Bacterial overgrowth • Impaired gut immunity

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following fluids contain lactate?
questions.explanation:
Ringer's lactate (sodium lactate solution) or Hartmann's solution is a mixture of sodium chloride, 
sodium lactate, potassium chloride, and calcium chloride in water. It is used for replacing fluids and electrolytes in those who have low blood volume or low blood 
pressure and to treat metabolic acidosis in cases other than those caused by lactic acidosis. It is 
also used to wash the eye following a chemical burn. The following table shows the composition of crystalloid and colloid solutions in (mmol/L). *Composition of Gelofusine is incorrect in Bailey 27th edition. Colloid Solution

questions.question: Question 17: What is the earliest sign of post-operative volume overload in a patient?
questions.explanation:
The earliest sign of volume overload in a patient is weight gain. The administration of isotonic fluids in excess of actual needs commonly results in excess volume 
expansion. This may be due to the overestimation of third-space losses or due to ongoing GI losses 
that are difficult to measure accurately. The average postoperative patient who is not receiving nutritional support should lose 
approximately 0.11 to 0.23 kg/day from catabolism. Other signs of volume overload include: Cardiac: • Increased cardiac output • Increased central venous pressure • Distended neck veins • Murmur GI: Bowel edema Pulmonary: Pulmonary edema

questions.question: Question 18: Ileus is common in patients that have conditions associated with
questions.explanation:
Ileus may occur in conditions associated with volume deficit. Ileus is a disruption of the normal propulsive ability of the gastrointestinal tract. The term is 
usually restricted to those disruptions caused by the failure of peristalsis, rather than by 
mechanical obstruction. Hypoperfusion to the bowel in a volume deficit state may result in ileus. The following table shows various signs and symptoms, in general, in conditions associated with 
volume deficit or overload. 21

questions.question:
Question 19: Which electrolyte abnormality is expected in patients experiencing a post-operative rise in 
ADH?
questions.explanation:
The post-operative rise in ADH (Antidiuretic hormone) may result in hyponatremia. Postoperative patients are usually prone to increased secretion of ADH, which causes an increase 
in reabsorption of free water from the kidneys resulting in volume expansion and hyponatremia. Dilutional hyponatremia occurs when there is an excess of extracellular water relative to sodium. 
However, it is self-limiting as both hyponatremia and volume expansion causes a decrease in ADH 
secretion.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is not an important cause of hypokalemia?
questions.explanation:
Hypokalemia may occur as a result of metabolic alkalosis, not metabolic acidosis. The following are various causes of hypokalemia: • Inadequate intake • Diet, potassium-free intravenous fluids, potassium deficient TPN • Excessive potassium excretion • Hyperaldosteronism • Medications • Potassium losses • Direct loss of potassium from GI fluid (diarrhea) • Renal loss of potassium (to conserve sodium in response to gastric losses) • Metabolic • Intracellular potassium shifts from metabolic alkalosis or insulin therapy Vomiting leads to hypokalemia via complex pathogenesis. The gastric fluid itself contains little 
potassium, approximately 10 mEq/L. However, vomiting produces volume depletion and 
metabolic alkalosis. 22 
Sold by @itachibot Volume depletion leads to secondary hyperaldosteronism leads to enhanced cortical collecting 
tubule secretion of potassium in response to enhanced sodium reabsorption. Metabolic alkalosis 
further increases potassium secretion by the collecting tubule due to the decreased availability of 
hydrogen ions.

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient with pancreatitis is most likely to have which of the following electrolyte 
abnormalities ?
questions.explanation:
Pancreatitis may lead to hypocalcemia. This is because inflammation of the pancreas, may lead to sequestration of the calcium via 
chelation with free fatty acids. Other causes of hypocalcemia: • Massive soft tissue infections such as necrotizing fasciitis • Renal failure • Pancreatic and small bowel fistulas • Hypoparathyroidism • Toxic shock syndrome • Abnormalities in magnesium levels • Tumor lysis syndrome

questions.question:
Question 22: A cachexic patient with a BMI of 14 was brought to a nursing care facility. Calorie-rich food 
through a nasogastric tube was started. On day 3 of therapy, the patient suddenly developed a 10 
Sold by @itachibot seizure. An ECG showed dysrhythmia. Which of the following findings is most likely?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of refeeding syndrome which results in hypophosphatemia, 
hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia. Refeeding syndrome is a potentially fatal condition that may occur due to rapid and excessive 
feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed 
nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients. With refeeding, a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate stimulates insulin 
release, which results in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, 
potassium, and calcium. These electrolyte disorders can result in altered myocardial function, 
arrhythmias, deteriorating respiratory function, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, 
tetany, and death. Severe hyperglycemia may result from blunted basal insulin secretion. It can occur with either 
enteral or parenteral nutrition but is more common with the latter. 23 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: Which of the following is not true regarding the Enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) 
protocol?
questions.explanation:
Waiting for one week to start oral feeding is not a part of the ERAS protocol. Enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) is an approach designed to speed the clinical recovery of 
the patient and reduce the cost and length of stay in the patient. It is achieved by optimizing the patient's health before surgery and then delivering evidence-based 
best care in the perioperative period. It includes: • Early planned physiotherapy and mobilisation • Early oral hydration and nourishment • Adequate pain control using regular paracetamol, NSAIDs, epidural and nerve blocks • Discharge planning is started before the patient is admitted to hospital and involves support 
from stoma care nurses, physiotherapist. • Early removal of ryles tube and early feeding techniques 24 
Sold by @itachibot Shock and Blood Transfusion
